description: How do you feel about Halloween this year?
What are more important - sports or politics, and why?
Has anything great happened at work lately?
Are you ready for 2018 to end? How are you feeling about 2019?
How would you feel if you won the lottery?
I feel comfortable explaining my team's goals and metrics
My leader links our discussions back to the team strategy
I ask questions about our team strategy and goals, when I want to learn more
I feel that my work is directly linked to the success of my team
Our strategy makes sense and seems to work well
Our team members share their frustrations with each other and get support from within the team
Our leader(s) make the necessary role changes to keep our team focused and motivated
I think my title is right, given my skills/goals/contributions
Our team leader is positive and keeps the work interesting
Our team makes decisions in a collaborative way, that take everyone's views into consideration
My team understands how we are supposed to work together and we focus on common goals
I am able to have tough conversations with my leader, without fearing for my job
My job is a good mix of learning and doing - I feel like I'm growing as a person
As I get better at my job, I take pride in my work and can see my career progression
My team knows when we are succeeding and we celebrate it
This job is rewarding in more ways than just financial
My leader makes me feel like I'm a valuable member of the team
I have the sense that my work makes a difference and my career matters
I come to work in part because I feel that I have purpose here
Hard work and big wins are recognized in my team
Some people in our team seem to thrive in this environment
I see some traits in my leader that I want to develop in myself
Some people in my team feel fulfilled doing this type of work
I feel more comfortable to be myself, the longer I'm in this job
Overall, I see signs of progress in our team, our members, and our organization
How do you constructively present reservations or recommendations to other people, about their work?
What's the difference between a solution that creates value for the whole company - versus just you personally?
What reasons do you have to share your ideas with your team? How - if at all - does it benefit you?
How do you / or how should you overcome objections to a suggestion you make in a team meeting?
How do you personally gain the confidence to present a new idea to your colleagues/leadership?
What personal tools / self-management techniques do you use to overcome disappointment or rejection?
How would you approach presenting an idea to upper management?
What techniques have you seen in your job - or elsewhere - that initiate good change?
How do you encourage other people to share their ideas?
What makes something "a good idea"?
The literal definition of "Ideology" is "study of ideas", how does your team study / think about new ideas?
Are you more likely to embrace new ideas, or trust the existing process/model of working?
What is the process for maturing an idea into a new way of doing business?
Explain your process for vetting a new idea or suggestion?
Describe your personal creative process:
How do you grow an idea into a full-fledge solution? What are the steps?
What can leadership do to be more accessible to your ideas?
How do you develop sponsorship and support for your ideas, before bringing them to leadership?
How do you allow people in your team to bring forward new ideas?
What does it take to catalyze a new idea, into part of your team's daily work
What is an example of a product we should NEVER EVER produce at our company?
How do you hold onto your ideas - even when they aren't initially accepted by your team?
What has been your relationship with change?
What role do emotions play in innovation and creativity?
How important is patience in the change process?
Our emotional preference is largely towards happiness. How do you inspire happiness in those around you?
How have leadership encouraged you in the past, when you were feeling discontent or frustrated?
What does it mean to be happy at work?
How do you use your work environment to your benefit concerning your level of daily contentment?
What words describe your path to a fulfilling day at work?
If celebrating each other's success is part of being in a high-performing team, what does this look like for you and your peers?
If you're feeling impatient with a situation or a coworker, how do you reverse the slide toward frustration and instead focus on fostering a nurturing environment?
What times during the day do you feel most unproductive, because of your emotional state?
What are some words that you hear that immediately form positive thoughts or ideas?
As humans, we can sense negativity before it becomes apparent. What techniques do you use to remain positive in those times?
What topics of non-work-related conversations foster an environment of happiness and connection with others?
A welcoming demeanor is crucial to growth and happiness in a team. In what ways do you maintain an inviting persona when interacting with others?
How do you form positive connections with others in the workplace, whilst maintaining a professional separation of home and work life?
In what ways does your personal life contribute to happiness in the work place?
In what ways does your work life promote happiness in your personal life?
How do you redeem happiness in the success of others?
In what situations do you find that leadership has been most effective at promoting a sense of unity in the workplace?
What is the difference between happiness and contentment to you, concerning your work life?
In what ways could you modify your current work experience, to encourage personal contentment?
Feeling instrumental to your company's success is crucial to personal happiness. How do you feel most effective?
Emotions typically have visible aesthetics. What does contentment look like?
How might a visitor to your work environment gage the level of happiness around them?
What are some subtle ways you can show others that you see and appreciate their contributions?
When you leave work for the day, how do you ensure that tomorrow you'll be happy to return?
When you find satisfaction in the short-term, what does that allow you to do in the long-term?
How do you mentally prepare to enter the office in the morning? Explain your ritual.
What are some ways that senior employees steamroll juniors - either on purpose or accidentally?
If a colleague reached out to you to 'check-in' while you are on vacation, how would that make you feel? Anxious? Appreciated?
In your own words, what is the current ethos of your team? If there isn't one, what would you like it to be?
When your day has gone all wrong, and it's still 11am, what will it take to get you back on a successful track?
What things do you need to consciously leave at home, when you enter the work place?
What words can others say to you, or actions can others take, to encourage you?
What methods do you use to separate from work, and be fully yourself at home?
What mental techniques are you familiar with to help you regulate your attitudes?
If you are having a bad day, but you need to be productive, how do you make that mental transition?
Among the different people in your life, co-workers deserve a unique set of boundaries. What are some examples of boundaries you should respect with co-workers?
If listening is about more than words, what are some things you've learned about your team members from watching them?
What are some techniques you have used to actively encourage someone?
What's the difference between "Reacting" and "Responding"?
Give examples of some positive things that EVERY person likes to hear:
How would you explain the working styles of your teammates? Or your team as a whole?
When is it ok for a junior person to disagree with their boss?
Do you prefer to work more solo, or as part of a team? And do you think you're able to do your best work currently?
What is your highest priority as a team
What one principle could your team adopt, that would result in a more productive environment?
If communication is more than words, what habits do you think are important to create harmony on the job?
How do you approach a disagreement with your boss, if for example you disagree with her/his suggestion on how to do your work?
What is your favorite quality about yourself?
Describe the characteristics of someone in the office that you've noticed and you admirer (names not required):
What does it mean to you if you were to receive a really positive compliment about your work product?
Why is daily celebration of success so important at work?
Most long-term projects go through cycles of success and failure - what do you say to yourself / how do you keep yourself engaged during the disappointments?
How do you encourage yourself to stick with something, even after it stops being "fun"?
Visualizing in our heads the tasks we need to do can put our subconscious wheels into motion; what are some things you find yourself visualizing before you do them?
In what ways does your involvement or your finger-prints on a project bring you joy, and make you a more fulfilled person?
What roles do affirmation and acknowledgement play when communicating with others?
As a principle, it is important to update plans as a project progresses and you learn new information - how can you apply this principle in your daily work?
How do you leverage your personal passions and your attention into your work, to deliver quality results?
How do you know when an idea is mature enough to be put into motion?
Everything we do improves with practice - what are some things you think your team is practicing and trying to master right now?
How do you ask for help when you are struggling to move forward?
Why is vision important to execution? In your mind how do the two relate?
Past experiences impact our decision-making; what experiences do you have that hold you back from action?
What are some of the signals you experience personally (emotional, psychological, physical) that indicate to you that you may need help?
What's an example of an instance where failure is more useful than success?
Who in your life do you turn to, when you're having problems and want encouragement / good advice?
How do you want your leaders and colleagues to motivate you?
Success is subjective; how do you allow yourself to feel successful?
How do you approach challenges where the outcome is unclear? How do you approach things that you are not confident in?
How do you treat execution of a project in such a way that it promotes success?
When you know you're doing the right thing, but it seems like there is a lot of resistance, how do you encourage yourself to keep going?
Why is it important to push through resistance, and claim small victories?
Celebrating success is important. How often and in what ways do you personally celebrate success?
How do you personally overcome the fear of failure?
Projects have momentum - sometimes it's smooth and quick, other times it slows to a crawl. Why is it important to modulate yourself and manage your own expectations through all these phases?
How do you find daily success, despite setbacks and frustration?
Even when plans change, the vision should stay generally the same. Why is this important?
Would you say your days are typically full of success and progress, or more frustration and dead-ends?
Even on the hardest days, what part of your job do you like/enjoy/find gratifying?
When people are frustrated at work - or when you're upset, how do you stay calm and focused? What do you tell yourself?
What percentage of your daily decisions do you make? Vs. your boss? Vs. agreed between you and your boss?
How complete does your work product have to be before you show it to your boss?
Why does your position matter - who is reliant on you and what do you do for them?
How much freedom do you have in your job to make decisions, do you think it's the right amount?
What are some ways you personally stay on the same page with your team members?
When someone is creating distractions in the work place, how do you respond? If you are the one creating distractions, how would you like others to respond?
When you are having a bad day, do you want people to pitch in and help? Or let you alone to figure it out?
When is an appropriate time to give someone feedback? Or is it more about approach?
How do you gently remind someone of a guideline, without being overbearing?
How do you ask for help, when you are struggling to move forward?
Does your team communicate more through conversations, emails, or non-verbal cues? And how well does this seem to work for you personally?
If you are doing something wrong, how do you want your boss to tell you? What about your peers, can they tell you?
How much original thinking or discretion is involved in your job? Is it too much? Too little?
When you need encouragement and motivation, where do you turn to get it?
How do you personally overcome the fear of failure
If one person in the team has a really strong opinion, does it usually win out? Or do different members pull together to balance out the decision-making process?
Why is vision important to execution?
How do you engage your personal passions and your attention into your work, to deliver quality results?
When someone is acting oddly, how do you handle being around them? Are you able to be polite and learn from them, even if they seem very different from you?
Celebrating success is important. Whose job is it in your team to celebrate success and highlight small wins?
If you see somebody doing something risky, how should you handle it?
What do you think is necessary for your personal safety, on a day to day basis? Equipment or otherwise...
When you think about safety in light of your personal life - what are you ultimately trying to protect?
What safety methods do you personally find comforting and reassuring?
What do you think keeps you from being the very safest on the job?
What aspects of your job are physically and emotionally hazardous?
What prevents you from pointing out improvements to safety?
How do you personally think through a situation to assess risk, both at work and on your personal time?
In what conditions do you think safety is extra important? What circumstances alert you that extra safety is necessary?
How do you keep emotions under control in high-stake situations?
When multiple people disagree about a safety situation, how is it typically resolved?
If someone thinks you are doing something wrong, how would you like them to approach you about it?
What do you do when you realize that you are the one not being safe in a situation?
What do you see as the most significant safety hazard of your current job? Is it physical? Is it mental? What is it?
When you start something, and then realize the approach is wrong, what do you do?
What do you typically do/think when you realize someone you work with is not being safe?
What do you wish leadership did differently, that would make the job safer?
There is often a trade-off between expedience to progress and safety; in your life and career, how do you think about this?
At any given time, we are either 1) becoming more comfortable with danger, or 2) becoming more protective from danger. Which direction do you feel the team needs to go?
Why is daily safe-keeping of our team critical to long-term business success?
What old mindsets are keeping us behind as a team or a company?
If safety meetings are not fully effective, what else should be done?
In what ways does your personal risk tolerance become a problem for your team?
Doing your job sometimes means assuming risks, how do you convince yourself that you are adequately prepared?
Good stewardship means taking care of what is entrusted to us. In what ways should we be good stewards of our teammates?
